label: def-mean-field-phase-space
nl_definition: The single-particle phase space, $\Omega$, is the Cartesian product of the valid position domain $X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ (a bounded, convex domain with a $C^2$ boundary) and the allowed velocity domain $V_{\text{alg}}$ (a closed ball of radius $V_{\text{alg}}$).

formal_conditions.text: Let $X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ be the bounded, convex domain with a $C^2$ boundary.
formal_conditions.latex: X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d \text{ is bounded, convex, with } \partial X_{\text{valid}} \text{ being } C^2

formal_conditions.text: Let $V_{\text{alg}} := \{v \in \mathbb{R}^d : \|v\| \le V_{\text{alg}}\}$ be the closed ball of allowed velocities.
formal_conditions.latex: V_{\text{alg}} := \{v \in \mathbb{R}^d : \|v\| \le V_{\text{alg}}\} \text{ is a closed ball}

formal_conditions.text: The single-particle phase space $\Omega$ is the Cartesian product of $X_{\text{valid}}$ and $V_{\text{alg}}$.

properties.name: Completeness
properties.description: Defines the complete set of possible kinematic states (position and velocity) for a single particle.

properties.name: Constraint Dependence
properties.description: Its structure directly translates the constraints imposed by the Euclidean Gas algorithm.

notes.text: The set of kinematic states includes both position and velocity components.

label: def-phase-space-density
nl_definition: The phase-space sub-probability density $f(t,z)$ describes the state of the alive population at time $t$, where integrating $f$ over any measurable subset $A$ of the phase space $\Omega$ yields the fraction of alive walkers whose state $(x, v)$ falls within $A$. The total mass of alive walkers, $m_a(t)$, is the integral of $f$ over the entire phase space $\Omega$, which must be less than or equal to 1.

formal_conditions.text: The domain of the density function $f$.
The mass of alive walkers in a subset $A \subseteq \Omega$ is given by the integral of $f$ over $A$.
formal_conditions.latex: \text{Alive mass in } A = \int_A f(t, z) dz

formal_conditions.text: The total mass of alive walkers $m_a(t)$.
The mass of dead walkers $m_d(t)$ in relation to the total mass.

properties.name: Total Mass Conservation
properties.description: The total mass (alive + dead) is conserved, $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$.

parameters.description: A point in the phase space $\Omega$ (representing position and velocity).
A measurable subset of the phase space $\Omega$, $A \subseteq \Omega$.
Total mass of alive walkers at time $t$.
Total mass of dead walkers at time $t$.

notes.text: The definition draws an analogy between integrating the probability density over a region in phase space and integrating population density over a neighborhood to find the number of people.

label: def-mean-field-moments
nl_definition: The Mean-Field Statistical Moments ($\mu_R[f], \sigma_R^2[f], \mu_D[f], \sigma_D^2[f]$) are specific functionals of the phase-space density $f(t,z)$, computed by taking expectations over the normalized alive population $f(t,z) / m_a(t)$, where $m_a(t)$ is the total alive mass.

formal_conditions.text: Total alive mass
Mean Reward Moment
Reward Variance Moment
Mean Distance Moment
Distance Variance Moment

parameters.description: Distance metric between transformed states $\varphi(z)$ and $\varphi(z')$.
Transformation function applied to the phase space variable.

notes.text: These functionals are used to replace empirical statistics calculated from the finite set of alive walkers in the N-particle system when transitioning to the continuous mean-field limit.

label: def-mean-field-patched-std
nl_definition: The Mean-Field Regularized Standard Deviations, denoted $\widehat{\sigma}_R[f](t)$ and $\widehat{\sigma}_D[f](t)$, are functionals of the density $f$ obtained by applying a regularization function $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}$ to the mean-field variance functionals $\sigma_R^2[f](t)$ and $\sigma_D^2[f](t)$, respectively.

notes.text: These functionals are introduced to preserve numerical stability and continuity guarantees, especially when the true variance $\sigma^2[f]$ is close to zero (high convergence).

label: def-mean-field-z-scores
nl_definition: The mean-field Z-scores, $\widetilde{r}[f](z,t)$ and $\widetilde{d}[f](z,z_c,t)$, are standardized representations of the raw observations $R(z)$ and the mapped distance $d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(z),\varphi(z_c))$, respectively, calculated by subtracting the corresponding global density-dependent moment ($\mu$) and dividing by its standard deviation ($\widehat{\sigma}$), all dependent on the system state $f$ and time $t$.

formal_conditions.text: The Z-scores are derived using density-dependent functionals.
The radial Z-score is defined as:
The distance Z-score is defined as:

properties.name: Standardization
properties.description: The scores are normalized using global, density-dependent moments (mean and standard deviation), resulting in standardized variables.

properties.name: Context Dependency
properties.description: The definition explicitly depends on the particle states ($z, z_c$), the system state $f$, and time $t$.

parameters.description: State of a potential companion particle.
Mean-field Z-score for the distance observation $d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(z),\varphi(z_c))$.
Raw measurement associated with state $z$ (implied context suggests a radial or positional observable).
Raw measurement of the distance between mapped states.
Global, density-dependent mean for the $R$ observable at time $t$.
Global, density-dependent standard deviation for the $R$ observable at time $t$.
Global, density-dependent mean for the distance observable $D$ at time $t$.
Global, density-dependent standard deviation for the distance observable $D$ at time $t$.

notes.text: These scores form the first step in constructing a potential, preceding the formation of the final, non-linear fitness potential.

label: def-mean-field-fitness-potential
nl_definition: The Mean-Field Fitness Potential $V[f](z, z_c, t)$ is a functional of the density $f$ that defines the fitness of a particle at state $z$ relative to a companion at $z_c$. It is the multiplicative combination of the rescaled diversity contribution and the rescaled reward contribution, both derived from mean-field Z-scores.

properties.name: Multiplicative Combination
properties.description: The potential combines the reward and diversity components multiplicatively.

properties.name: Functional Dependence
properties.description: The value depends on the global shape of the probability distribution $f$.

parameters.description: Mean-Field Fitness Potential, a functional of the density $f$.
The state of the companion particle.

notes.text: This structure allows the algorithm to balance the drive for high rewards (exploitation) with the need to maintain diversity (exploration).

label: def-baoab-update-rule
nl_definition: The BAOAB (B-A-O-A-B) method computes the state update $(x_{n+1}, v_{n+1})$ from $(x_n, v_n)$ over a time step $\tau$ by symmetrically splitting the integration into five sequential substeps: a half-step force kick (B), a half-step position drift (A), a full-step Ornstein-Uhlenbeck integration (O) for velocity incorporating thermal noise, another half-step position drift (A), and a final half-step force kick (B).

formal_conditions.text: Time update relation
B-Step 1 (Force Kick)
A-Step 1 (Position Drift)
O-Step (Ornstein-Uhlenbeck)
A-Step 2 (Position Drift)
B-Step 2 (Force Kick)

properties.name: Symmetry
properties.description: The method is constructed symmetrically around the O-step (integrator for the velocity involving noise/friction).

properties.name: Structure
properties.description: It is a splitting method that analytically solves the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck part (often used for simulating Langevin dynamics or Brownian motion with friction/temperature).

properties.name: Order
properties.description: Typically yields a second-order accurate integration scheme when used within standard SDE contexts.

parameters.description: Position of the particle at time $t_n$
Velocity of the particle at time $t_n$
Position of the particle at time $t_{n+1}$
Velocity of the particle at time $t_{n+1}$
Intermediate velocity after the first B-step
Intermediate position after the first A-step
Flow field evaluated at the midpoint $x_{n+1/2}$
Friction coefficient in the OU process

notes.text: This rule is derived from the Euclidean Gas specification, implying the underlying dynamics follow SDEs typically associated with molecular dynamics or stochastic simulations.

label: def-kinetic-generator
nl_definition: The kinetic transport operator $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$ is the infinitesimal generator of the Fokker-Planck equation governing the evolution of the probability density function for the set of alive walkers $\mathcal{A}$ under the influence of an underdamped Langevin SDE, subject to reflecting boundary conditions on position and velocity.

properties.name: Generator
properties.description: It is the infinitesimal generator for the N-particle system described by independent underdamped Langevin SDEs.

properties.name: Mathematical Form
properties.description: It is expressed as the sum of advection terms (from $\mathrm d x_i$ and the drift of $\mathrm d v_i$) and a diffusion term ($\frac{\sigma_v^2}{2} \Delta_{v_i} f$).

properties.name: Boundary Dependence
properties.description: It incorporates the effects of kinetic transport boundaries (reflecting on position and velocity cap).

parameters.description: index for a single alive walker
Mass of the walker (implied from context/Euclidean Gas)
Force acting on walker i at position x_i
External mean velocity field at position x_i
Diffusion coefficient for velocity (related to temperature/noise magnitude)
Boundary of the valid position domain
Maximum allowed velocity magnitude (velocity ball radius)
Velocity cap function/operator (related to boundary condition)
Test function on the swarm state space
Laplacian operator with respect to v_i

notes.text: The SDE described is the continuous-time counterpart to the BAOAB integrator approximation.
The terms in $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$ correspond to advection ($v_i\cdot\nabla_{x_i}$), deterministic drift (force and friction), and stochastic diffusion ($\frac{\sigma_v^2}{2}\,\Delta_{v_i} f$).
The operator acts on the probability density over the $N$-particle phase space, constrained by the physical domain.

label: def-killing-operator
nl_definition: The interior killing operator is implicitly defined by the killing rate $c(z)$, which removes mass from the alive density $f$ at a rate proportional to $c(z)f(z)$. The total mass killed per unit time is given by the functional $k_{\text{killed}}[f](t)$.

formal_conditions.text: Safety in the interior: The killing rate is zero in a safe subset of the domain.
formal_conditions.latex: c(z) = 0 \text{ for all } z \text{ in a safe subset of } \Omega \text{ away from the position boundary.

formal_conditions.text: Activity near the boundary: The killing rate is positive in a smooth transition layer near the boundary.
formal_conditions.latex: c(z) > 0 \text{ in a smooth transition layer near } \partial X_{\text{valid}} \times V_{\text{alg}}.

formal_conditions.text: Smoothness of the killing rate.

properties.name: Mass Removal Rate
properties.description: The mass is removed from the alive density $f$ at a rate $c(z)f(z)$.

properties.name: Total Mass Killed
properties.description: The total mass killed per unit time is given by the functional $k_{\text{killed}}[f](t) = \int_{\Omega} c(z) f(t,z) \, \mathrm{d}z$.

parameters.description: Alive density function (implicitly dependent on time $t$ and space $z$)

notes.text: The function $c$ must be smooth ($C^\infty$) to ensure regularity of PDE solutions involving this operator.

label: def-revival-operator
nl_definition: The Revival Operator $B[f, m_d](t, z)$ models the re-injection of mass from the dead population back into the alive population, defined as proportional to the current alive density normalized by the total alive mass, multiplied by the total dead mass and a constant revival rate $\lambda_{\text{revive}}$.

formal_conditions.text: The revival rate is strictly positive.
The dead mass $m_d(t)$ is defined as $1 - m_a(t)$, where $m_a(t)$ is the alive mass.

properties.name: Revival Mechanism
properties.description: The spatial profile of re-injected mass is proportional to the current normalized alive density $f(t,z)/m_a(t)$, reflecting cloning from alive companions.

properties.name: Total Revived Mass Rate
properties.description: The total mass revived per unit time, integrated over the domain $\Omega$, is $\lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d(t)$.

parameters.description: The spatial distribution of the alive population (alive density)
The Revival Operator acting on alive density f and dead mass m_d

notes.text: This operator acts as a source term in the evolution equation for the alive population density.
Typical values for the revival rate $\lambda_{\text{revive}}$ are between 0.1 and 5.

label: def-cloning-generator
nl_definition: The **Internal Cloning Operator**, denoted $S[f]$, is the mass-neutral, non-local operator representing the mean-field limit of a discrete cloning mechanism, decomposed into source and sink terms based on the density $f(t,z)$.

formal_conditions.text: The operator $S[f]$ is defined as the difference between its source ($S_{\text{src}}$) and sink ($S_{\text{sink}}$) terms.
formal_conditions.latex: S[f](t, z) = S_{\text{src}}[f](t, z) - S_{\text{sink}}[f](t, z)

formal_conditions.text: The sink term, where mass is removed when walkers at $z$ clone away.
The source term, where mass is gained when walkers from other states clone to $z$.
formal_conditions.latex: S_{\text{src}}[f](t,z) = \frac{1}{\tau m_a(t)} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(t,z_d) f(t,z_c) P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c) Q_{\delta}(z \mid z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c

formal_conditions.text: Mass neutrality condition (integration over the state space $\Omega$ yields zero).

properties.name: Mass Neutrality
properties.description: The operator is constructed to be mass-neutral, meaning its integral over the state space $\Omega$ is zero, as demonstrated by the cancellation between the integrated source and sink terms.

properties.name: Non-Local
properties.description: The operator involves integrals over the entire state space $\Omega$, making it non-local.

properties.name: Decomposition
properties.description: It decomposes into an explicit sink term ($S_{\text{sink}}$) and a source term ($S_{\text{src}}$).

parameters.description: The Internal Cloning Operator itself, dependent on the density $f$.
Position variable in the state space $\Omega$.
The source term of the operator.
The sink term of the operator.
The cloning probability depending on fitness values computed from the normalized alive density $f/m_a$.
The jitter kernel (Gaussian in position, delta in velocity).

notes.text: This operator is the continuum limit of a discrete cloning mechanism, where $\tau$ is the discrete timestep.
The operator $S[f]$ appears in the kinetic equation describing the evolution of the density $f$ under cloning dynamics.

label: def-transport-operator
nl_definition: The Transport Operator, $L^\dagger$, is the formal $L^2$-adjoint of the backward kinetic generator $L$, and it describes the local transport of probability density via drift and diffusion through the negative divergence of the probability flux vector $J[f]$.

formal_conditions.text: The Transport Operator $L^\dagger$ is the formal $L^2$-adjoint of $L$ (the backward kinetic generator).
The Transport Operator is written in conservative form as the negative divergence of the probability flux vector $J[f]$:
Definition of the Positional Flux ($J_x$): Advection plus Fickian Diffusion.
Definition of the Velocity Flux ($J_v$): Drift plus Fickian Diffusion.

properties.name: Adjoint Relationship
properties.description: It is the formal $L^2$-adjoint of the backward kinetic generator $L$.

properties.name: Conservative Form
properties.description: It is represented as the negative divergence of the probability flux vector $J[f]$.

properties.name: Physical Interpretation
properties.description: Describes local transport of probability density via drift and diffusion.

parameters.description: The backward kinetic generator from Section 2.2.
The Transport Operator, which is the formal $L^2$-adjoint of $L$.
The density function upon which $L^\dagger$ acts.

notes.text: The kinetic part of the evolution, described by the generator $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$, corresponds to a local transport of probability density via drift and diffusion. The representation of $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$ in the forward equation is given by its formal adjoint, which is the Fokker-Planck operator, represented here by $L^\dagger$.
